Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in New Zealand
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Scott Seyfarth of the University of California, San Diego to conduct a research project in the Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences area during the summer of 2013 at the University of Canterbury in Christchurch, New Zealand. The project title is "Usage-Based Factors for Vowel Change in New Zealand English." The host scientist is Elizabeth Hume.

This project uses data from a large historical speech corpus hosted at the University of Canterbury to study causes for vowel change in New Zealand English. The corpus is being evaluated for the contribution of usage variables, such as word predictability, the probabilities of different vowel types, and the salience of near-homophones, to vowel centralization and the front vowel shift in New Zealand English. These factors have been shown to influence vowel articulation in everyday speech, and so the goal is to assess whether they may also have influenced the long-term vowel changes in progress, or whether the changes are better accounted for by sociolinguistic analysis. The project contributes to scholarship on vowel system typology, phonetic category maintenance, and the phonetics and phonology of New Zealand English over the last century.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, this research promotes the exchange of work being done on the sound systems of global Englishes, including among the multi-disciplinary, international linguistics and cognition researchers at the New Zealand Institute of Language, Brain, and Behavior. The results of the research will contribute to the Origins of New Zealand English Project at the Institute, and will be shared with the wider linguistics community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded a project to extract spectral information from the recorded speech of New Zealand English speakers born since 1851, and to analyze the results in order to better understand the processes and directions of vowel change in New Zealand speech. The Origins of New Zealand English (ONZE) Project includes three large corpora containing over a million words of speech produced by New Zealand speakers, with recordings starting in the 1940s. For this EAPSI grant, the Forced Alignment & Vowel Extraction (FAVE) program suite, originally developed at the University of Pennsylvania, was modified for use with the ONZE corpora. Roughly half a million vowel articulations from around 500 speakers were automatically extracted from the corpora. Formant frequencies and bandwidths were measured, which provide characteristic information about vowel quality. The dataset was speaker-normalized and stored for use by researchers at the New Zealand Institute of Language, Brain, and Behaviour.

After creation of the dataset, several historical vowel changes were evaluated for whether and how usage variables contributed to the change. These changes include the fronting of the vowel in words like 'goose' over time (in New Zealand English, 'noose' sounds like 'nurse'); the short front vowel shift (which affects the vowels in 'trap', 'dress', and 'kit'); the fronting of the vowel in words like 'start' over time ('cart' sounds closer to 'cat' than in many other English dialects); and a merger that causes words like 'cheer' and 'chair' (for example: fear/fair, here/hair) to be homophones. Usage variables include factors like the contexts in which the vowel types and the words containing those vowels are used; the phonological relationships of these words to other English words; how easy it was at different points in New Zealand history to confuse these words and vowels with similar words and vowels; and the frequency and likelihood with which these words and vowels occurred in New Zealand English speech. The investigation into the role of word frequency is currently part of an ongoing study. More generally, the vowel spectrum data generated from this project may be useful outside the field for practical applications such as automated speech recognition and synthesis.
